bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, September 6, 1917

div1.p: Kean discusses the command structure of the Ambulance Corps in France.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to William Crawford Gorgas, September 6, 1917
div1.opener:
jrk-oh
France - 6th September 1917
My dear General:
div1.p:
I am sending you herewith an official letter giving the status of my service at
present.

I am doing everything that I can to meet the wishes of the two hostile factions
and to harmonize a very difficult situation. Mr. Norton is perhaps right in his
refusal to accept a commission which will involve his serving in the same office
with Mr. Andrew, because the two men are so hostile to each other that it is per-
haps impossible for them to get along together. I am anxious, however, to give
full recognition to the Harjes-Norton units and to the Red Cross which is behind
them, and have accordingly offered the majority which has been refused by Mr. Norton
and his assistant Mr. Kemp, to another one of his assistants, Mr. Stelle. This
has been done with the full approval of Major Perkins, who is in charge of the
Military Division of the Red Cross, and Mr. Norton. Mr. Stelle has impressed both
Colonel Jones and myself very favorably, and I believe will make a useful officer.

I wish that you would lay your commands on one of your numerous assistants, either
Furbush or Birmingham, to write and tell us the news of the Corps, as we feel in
outer darkness as far as news is concerned. No one has received even a service
paper.
With cordial regards to my friends in the office, and to Mrs. Gorgas, I am,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Kean Inclosure.
Major General W. C. Gorgas, USA
Surgeon General
War Department
Washington, D. C.
